When comparing plant-based calcium sources with cow-based sources, several factors should be considered. Plant sources of calcium, such as leafy greens, nuts, and seeds, are often high in other nutrients like fiber, antioxidants, and vitamins, which can contribute to overall health. In contrast, cow-based sources of calcium like dairy products provide a more concentrated dose of calcium along with protein and other essential nutrients. 

However, the bioavailability of calcium can vary between plant and cow sources. While the calcium in dairy products is generally well-absorbed by the body, some plant sources contain compounds that can inhibit calcium absorption. To enhance the absorption of plant-based calcium, it is important to consume a variety of calcium-rich plant foods and pair them with sources of vitamin D, which aids in calcium absorption. 

Ultimately, whether plant or cow-based sources of calcium are better for an individual depends on their dietary preferences, health goals, and overall nutrient intake. A balanced diet that includes a mix of both plant and animal-based calcium sources can help ensure adequate calcium intake to support bone health and overall well-being.

When considering calcium sources, plant-based options and cow-derived sources come to mind. Plant-based calcium sources include leafy greens, almonds, and tofu, while cow-derived calcium typically comes from dairy products like milk and cheese. Each source has its own benefits and considerations. Plant-based calcium is often more easily absorbed by the body due to the presence of other nutrients that aid in absorption. Additionally, plant-based sources are often lower in saturated fats and may be more environmentally friendly. On the other hand, cow-derived calcium is a more concentrated source of the mineral and provides high-quality protein. Ultimately, the choice between plant and cow calcium depends on individual preferences, dietary needs, and ethical considerations.

Soymilk is often consumed to reduce menopausal symptoms, although in its native form, it contains significantly less calcium than cow's milk. Moreover, when calcium is added as a fortificant, it may not be absorbed efficiently. This study compares calcium absorption from soymilk fortified with a proprietary phosphate of calcium versus absorption from cow's milk. Paleolithic vs. modern diets--selected pathophysiological implications.	The nutritional patterns of Paleolithic humans influenced genetic evolution during the time segment within which defining characteristics of contemporary humans were selected. Our genome can have changed little since the beginnings of agriculture, so, genetically, humans remain Stone Agers--adapted for a Paleolithic dietary regimen. Such diets were based chiefly on wild game, fish and uncultivated plant foods. They provided abundant protein; a fat profile much different from that of affluent Western nations; high fibre; carbohydrate from fruits and vegetables (and some honey) but not from cereals, refined sugars and dairy products; high levels of micronutrients and probably of phytochemicals as well.
